meeting_annotations.speaker: Wei Min

meeting_annotations.speaker: Wei Min
meeting_annotations.transcript: Oh, okay, so um well, we do a lot of different things uh including the instrumentation development of uh uh non linear Rama microscopy and then the uh imaging probe development because uh I think Rama was traditionally considered as a label free technique but we gradually realized that uh uh if we introduce some uh cleverly designed probes just like what fluorescent community has been doing, we actually could enhance the functionalities of Rama uh microscopy uh significantly. For example, the um you know, we can make very small tag so that we can label small molecules and that way we can uh enhance the sensitivity and also the specificity of small molecule detection. Uh another approach we uh worked on is to increase the multiplexity. So I think uh we just mentioned that Rama, I mean fluorescence can only limited to uh seven just just mentioned uh fluorescence typically limited to four colors. But Rama can go significantly beyond that uh but because of the linewidth. So we engineered uh Raman probes that has very very sharp lines and then we make them uh all resolve from each other. So we can have a library of well resolved Raman uh probes then we can image them uh simultaneously. So the current uh we can we can go up to like 20 colors at the same time. So that's something I think Rama can really go beyond fluorescence. Again, because of the new probes we introduced.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Wei Min

So the ability change upon like citation is high, so that will typically leads to high cross section.
